comments.text:  inf returns positive infinity if sign >= 0, negative infinity if sign < 0.
 is_nan reports whether f is an IEEE 754 ``not-a-number'' value.
 is_inf reports whether f is an infinity, according to sign.
 If sign > 0, is_inf reports whether f is positive infinity.
 If sign < 0, is_inf reports whether f is negative infinity.
 If sign == 0, is_inf reports whether f is either infinity.

contents.content: fn is_inf(f f64, sign int) bool
contents.name: is_inf

comments.text:  is_finite returns true if f is finite
 normalize returns a normal number y and exponent exp
 satisfying x == y × 2**exp. It assumes x is finite and non-zero.
 The vlang code is a modified version of the original C code from
 http://www.netlib.org/fdlibm/s_cbrt.c and came with this notice.
 Copyright (C) 1993 by Sun Microsystems, Inc. All rights reserved.
 Developed at SunSoft, a Sun Microsystems, Inc. business.
 Permission to use, copy, modify, and distribute this
 software is freely granted, provided that this notice
 cbrt returns the cube root of a.
 max is the largest finite value representable by the type.
 smallest_non_zero is the smallest positive, non-zero value representable by the type.
 -9223372036854775808 is wrong, because C compilers parse literal values
 without sign first, and 9223372036854775808 overflows i64, hence the
 mod returns the floating-point remainder of x/y.
 The magnitude of the result is less than y and its
 sign agrees with that of x.

contents.content: fn mod(x f64, y f64) f64
contents.name: mod

comments.text:  fmod returns the floating-point remainder of number / denom (rounded towards zero)

contents.content: fn fmod(x f64, y f64) f64
contents.name: fmod

comments.text:  gcd calculates greatest common (positive) divisor (or zero if a and b are both zero).

contents.content: fn gcd(a_ i64, b_ i64) i64
contents.name: gcd

comments.text:  egcd returns (gcd(a, b), x, y) such that |a*x + b*y| = gcd(a, b)

contents.content: fn egcd(a i64, b i64) (i64, i64, i64)
contents.name: egcd

contents.content: fn lcm(a i64, b i64) i64
contents.name: lcm

comments.text:  erf returns the error function of x.
 erfc returns the complementary error function of x.
 exp returns e**x, the base-e exponential of x.
 exp2 returns 2**x, the base-2 exponential of x.

contents.content: fn ldexp(frac f64, exp int) f64
contents.name: ldexp

comments.text:  frexp breaks f into a normalized fraction
 and an integral power of two.
 It returns frac and exp satisfying f == frac × 2**exp,
 with the absolute value of frac in the interval [½, 1).
 factorial calculates the factorial of the provided value.
 log_factorial calculates the log-factorial of the provided value.
 factoriali returns 1 for n <= 0 and -1 if the result is too large for a 64 bit integer
 floor returns the greatest integer value less than or equal to x.
 ceil returns the least integer value greater than or equal to x.
 trunc returns the integer value of x.
 round returns the nearest integer, rounding half away from zero.
 Returns the rounded float, with sig_digits of precision.

contents.content: fn round_sig(x f64, sig_digits int) f64
contents.name: round_sig

comments.text:  round_to_even returns the nearest integer, rounding ties to even.
 gamma returns the gamma function of x.
 log_gamma returns the natural logarithm and sign (-1 or +1) of Gamma(x).
 log_gamma_sign returns the natural logarithm and sign (-1 or +1) of Gamma(x)
 hypot returns the hypotenuse of the triangle give two sides

contents.content: fn hypot(x f64, y f64) f64
contents.name: hypot

comments.text:  acosh returns the non-negative area hyperbolic cosine of x
 asinh returns the area hyperbolic sine of x
 atanh returns the area hyperbolic tangent of x
 atan returns the arctangent, in radians, of x.
 atan2 returns the arc tangent of y/x, using
 the signs of the two to determine the quadrant

contents.content: fn atan2(y f64, x f64) f64
contents.name: atan2

comments.text:
Floating-point arcsine and arccosine.

	They are implemented by computing the arctangent
	after appropriate range reduction.
 asin returns the arcsine, in radians, of x.
 asin(x) = nan if x < -1 or x > 1
 acos returns the arccosine, in radians, of x.
 acos(x) = nan if x < -1 or x > 1
 maxof returns the maximum value of the type `T`
 minof returns the minimum value of the type `T`
 log returns the natural logarithm of x (float64)
 log returns the natural logarithm of x (float32)
 log_n returns log base b of x

contents.content: fn log_n(x f64, b f64) f64
contents.name: log_n

comments.text:  log10 returns the decimal logarithm of x.
 The special cases are the same as for log.
 log2 returns the binary logarithm of x.
 The special cases are the same as for log.
 log_b returns the binary exponent of x.
 ilog_b returns the binary exponent of x as an integer.
 aprox_sin returns an approximation of sin(a) made using lolremez
 aprox_cos returns an approximation of cos(a) made using lolremez
 copysign returns a value with the magnitude of x and the sign of y

contents.content: fn copysign(x f64, y f64) f64
contents.name: copysign

comments.text:  degrees converts an angle in radians to a corresponding angle in degrees.
 angle_diff calculates the difference between angles in radians

contents.content: fn angle_diff(radian_a f64, radian_b f64) f64
contents.name: angle_diff
DigitParams

comments.text:  digits returns an array of the digits of `num` in the given optional `base`.
 The `num` argument accepts any integer type (i8|i16|int|isize|i64), and will be cast to i64
 The `base:` argument is optional, it will default to base: 10.
 This function returns an array of the digits in reverse order i.e.:
 You can also use it, with an explicit `reverse: true` parameter,
 (it will do a reverse of the result array internally => slower):
 count_digits return the number of digits in the number passed.
 Number argument accepts any integer type (i8|i16|int|isize|i64) and will be cast to i64
 minmax returns the minimum and maximum value of the two provided.

contents.content: fn minmax(a f64, b f64) (f64, f64)
contents.name: minmax

comments.text:  clamp returns x constrained between a and b

contents.content: fn clamp(x f64, a f64, b f64) f64
contents.name: clamp

comments.text:  sign returns the corresponding sign -1.0, 1.0 of the provided number.
 if n is not a number, its sign is nan too.
 signi returns the corresponding sign -1, 1 of the provided number.
 radians converts an angle in degrees to a corresponding angle in radians.
 signbit returns a value with the boolean representation of the sign for x
 tolerance checks if a and b difference are less than or equal to the tolerance value

contents.content: fn tolerance(a f64, b f64, tol f64) bool
contents.name: tolerance

comments.text:  close checks if a and b are within 1e-14 of each other

contents.content: fn close(a f64, b f64) bool
contents.name: close

comments.text:  veryclose checks if a and b are within 4e-16 of each other

contents.content: fn veryclose(a f64, b f64) bool
contents.name: veryclose

comments.text:  alike checks if a and b are equal

contents.content: fn alike(a f64, b f64) bool
contents.name: alike

comments.text:  min returns the minimum of `a` and `b`

contents.content: fn min[T](a T, b T) T
contents.name: min

comments.text:  max returns the maximum of `a` and `b`

contents.content: fn max[T](a T, b T) T
contents.name: max

comments.text:  abs returns the absolute value of `a`
 modf returns integer and fractional floating-point numbers
 that sum to f. Both values have the same sign as f.
 nextafter32 returns the next representable f32 value after x towards y.

contents.content: fn nextafter32(x f32, y f32) f32
contents.name: nextafter32

comments.text:  nextafter returns the next representable f64 value after x towards y.

contents.content: fn nextafter(x f64, y f64) f64
contents.name: nextafter

comments.text:  pow returns the base x, raised to the provided power y. (float64)

contents.content: fn pow(x f64, y f64) f64
contents.name: pow

comments.text:  powf returns the base a, raised to the provided power b. (float32)

contents.content: fn powf(a f32, b f32) f32
contents.name: powf

comments.text:  pow10 returns 10**n, the base-10 exponential of n.
 powi returns base raised to power (a**b) as an integer (i64)
 powi(a, b) = -1 for a = 0 and b < 0

contents.content: fn powi(a i64, b i64) i64
contents.name: powi

comments.text:  scalbn scales x by FLT_RADIX raised to the power of n, returning the same as:

contents.content: fn scalbn(x f64, n_ int) f64
contents.name: scalbn

comments.text:  sincos calculates the sine and cosine of the angle in radians
 cosh returns the hyperbolic cosine of x in radians
 sqrt calculates square-root of the provided value. (float64)
 sqrtf calculates square-root of the provided value. (float32)
 sqrti calculates the integer square-root of the provided value. (i64)
 square returns the square of the argument x, i.e. x * x
 cube returns the cube of the argument x, i.e. x * x * x
 tan calculates tangent of a number
 tan calculates cotangent of a number
 tanh returns the hyperbolic tangent of x.
 f32_bits returns the IEEE 754 binary representation of f,
 with the sign bit of f and the result in the same bit position.
 f32_from_bits returns the floating-point number corresponding
 to the IEEE 754 binary representation b, with the sign bit of b
 and the result in the same bit position.
 f64_bits returns the IEEE 754 binary representation of f,
 with the sign bit of f and the result in the same bit position,
 f64_from_bits returns the floating-point number corresponding
 to the IEEE 754 binary representation b, with the sign bit of b
 and the result in the same bit position.
 with_set_low_word sets low word of `f` to `lo`

contents.content: fn with_set_low_word(f f64, lo u32) f64
contents.name: with_set_low_word

comments.text:  with_set_high_word sets high word of `f` to `lo`

contents.content: fn with_set_high_word(f f64, hi u32) f64
contents.name: with_set_high_word

comments.text:  get_high_word returns high part of the word of `f`.
